title: 114_hr5203
content: The "Visa Integrity and Security Act of 2016" is cited as the short title. It amends the Immigration and Nationality Act by adding a new section on petition and application processing for visas and immigration benefits. The "Visa Integrity and Security Act of 2016" requires all petitions and applications related to visas or immigration to be signed by the necessary parties. Immigrant visa applications must be signed in the presence of a consular officer and verified by the applicant's oath. The "Visa Integrity and Security Act of 2016" mandates that all visa and immigration petitions or applications must be fully completed before approval. Additionally, any document in a foreign language must be accompanied by a certified English translation for consular officer acceptance. Requests for additional information may be made by the Secretary of Homeland Security or consular officers. All visa and immigration petitions or applications must be fully completed with all requested information provided before approval. Failure to meet deadlines for providing additional information may result in the petition or application not being approved. "SEC. 211B. BACKGROUND CHECKS AND OTHER SCREENING REQUIREMENTS." SEC. 211B requires a comprehensive security and background check for visa petitions and applications to determine national security threats. Additionally, a security advisory opinion is required before issuing a nonimmigrant or immigrant visa. SEC. 211B mandates a security advisory opinion for certain aliens, including nationals of specified countries or those deemed appropriate by the Secretary of State, before issuing a visa. SEC. 211B mandates a security advisory opinion for certain aliens applying for specific visa categories or for NATO visas. The background check includes reviewing the alien's publicly available social media activity. The text discusses the requirement for DNA testing to confirm biological relationships in immigration petitions or applications. Additionally, it mentions the review of an alien's social media interactions as part of the background check process. The Immigration and Nationality Act requires in-person interviews for aliens applying for benefits, except for work authorization. The Secretary of Homeland Security may waive this requirement for aliens under 10 years old. Section 211A discusses petition and application processing, while Section 211B addresses background checks and screening requirements. A conforming amendment is made to Section 222(e) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The amendments apply to applications and petitions filed after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Section 3 focuses on fraud prevention measures. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to submit a plan for using advanced analytics software to detect fraud in immigration benefits applications and ensure national security within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Implementation of the plan must begin within 1 year. The Secretary of Homeland Security must complete a benefit fraud assessment by fiscal year 2021 for various immigration applications and petitions, including those for VAWA self-petitioners, spouses under certain visa categories, individuals applying for U visas, and other specific visa categories. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit findings and recommendations on reducing fraud in various immigration applications and petitions to Congress within 30 days of completing each benefit fraud assessment. SEC. 4. VISA SECURITY PROGRAM. The Secretary of State is authorized to charge surcharges for visa security funding starting in fiscal year 2016. The collected funds will be credited to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and available until expended for Visa Security. The Secretary of State can charge surcharges for visa security funding, with the collected funds available for the Visa Security Program costs. Additionally, twenty percent of funds collected under the Diplomatic and Consular Programs heading will be repaid into the Treasury as repayment of appropriated funds. The Visa Integrity and Security Act of 2016 requires the Department of Homeland Security to assign employees to diplomatic and consular posts where visas are issued within 4 years of enactment. Employees will review visa applications and supporting documents. The Visa Integrity and Security Act of 2016 mandates the review of visa applications and supporting documents before adjudication. Additionally, within one year of assignment, personnel at diplomatic or consular posts must be stationed and accommodated to carry out their duties. Authorization of $60,000,000 for fiscal years 2017 and 2018 to expedite implementation of Homeland Security Act section 428(e). SEC. 5 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require clear and convincing evidence for applications. SEC. 6 mandates a GAO report. The Comptroller General of the United States will review and report to Congress on the security of nonimmigrant and immigrant visa application processes, including how security screening and background checks are conducted and considered by the Departments of Homeland Security and State. Agency cooperation is also required in these processes. The Comptroller General will review security screening and background checks for visa applications and agencies must cooperate by providing access to records and information.
